Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: I know  this has been discussed at length but I'm asking anyway.:) I  am on my off week of 3rd cycle of Xeloda. I naively thought I might escape diarrhea but it found me. 2 days ago. It hit with vengeance llast night and awful today. Barely appetite and eating really bland foods. Their doing a poo culture before they prescribe anything or cut dosage so just taking Imodium. For most of you do you have days during cycle it's worse or is this a constant of xeloda? "Be Brave" Dx 6/19/2010, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Surgery 11/29/2010 Mastectomy: Right Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/28/2012 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 11/28/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Xeloda and Big D Bondgirl

Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: My first indication of my progression to stage IV were rising tumor markers. My local onco runs one tm test and my MDA oncologist runs the other two. I'm on perjeta/herceptin/taxotere. At the end of January scans at MDA showed resolution of liver met, possible progression in lungs (although unknown tumor size due to infection and inflammation in lungs so radiologist said progression and onco said no way to know). Also, spots on spine to be confirmed by bone scans end of next month. Anyway, one tm at MDA was down very slightly and the other up a little after 3 treatments. After 4th treatment here at home markers up from high 280's to low 360's although they are still pleased with liver scan and are not changing anything until my markers from today come back. Then I presume they will send me for earlier scans. Sigh. Anyway, I know markers can rise with initial chemo but like I said doing round 5 today. Just so frustrating as I want this to work....as we all do. Any experiences anyone can add for those of you that generally have reliable markers? Did you see rises later in treatment or rising markers combined with regression and progression. Also, I don't necessarily see these as high jumps although it's disheartening nonetheless. This stage IV business is such a roller coaster. Just keep reminding myself that beyond the treatments that it is all in God's hands. Thanks ladies "Be Brave" Dx 6/19/2010, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Surgery 11/29/2010 Mastectomy: Right Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/28/2012 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 11/28/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Advice on tumor markers Bondgirl chele

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2013 02:19PM Bondgirl wrote: Hi ladies. I'm six days out from my first TDM1 treatment. I felt fine day of and day after but the queasiness hit me the third day with the worst being over the weekend.  I still have had lingering queasiness the last two days.  My appetite comes and goes from apples for dinner to ravenous at other times.  I'm also having some taste bud issues. Not to the same extent at taxotere and perjeta but everything is a little off or leaves a bad after taste. Anyone else? Also since my infusion some of my mets symptoms have been more pronounced. I have lung, liver and bone.  I've had heaviness/breathlessness in my chest since Sunday that comes and goes in terms of severity. I've also had some neck pain.  Anyone on any type of chemo have physical signs of regression. I imagining that my lung tumor is breaking up or something and that is why its bothering me. Wishful thinking?  Lol. I won't know anything until tumor markers are ran at next treatment.  I'm putting so much hope in this drug and I just don't want to be disappointed obviously. Anyway, how is everyone else doing on this? Thanks for any input!
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2013 03:44AM Bondgirl wrote: Hi ladies. I progressed a lot on perjeta/herceptin/taxotere as many of you. Hope to start TDM1 on Wednesday! I'm excited but super nervous that this will not be my "miracle drug". Had so much hope for p/h/t. So I understand no per-meds...does that mean no steroids day before, of, and after? It sounds like most of you are dealing with 3 days or so of crappiness which sounds manageable to me. I can care for myself on p/h/t although my hubby took great care of me those first few days after each treatment but I have a 4 year old and was unable to do much for her those bad days. Hoping to feel more like myself on this and not be in that chemo fog for days followed by a 2 day hangover. Really praying for this one. Good luck to you all! Tera
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2013 03:11PM Bondgirl wrote: I am still anxiously awaiting starting TDM1. It's been a month since I have had any treatment whatsoever and the stress is weighing heavily. There was some sort of communication breakdown between MDA and my local oncologist office (plus I was at Disney when local oncologist was trying to get ahold of me). The pre-cert was submitted to insurance last week as an expedite so I have been stalking them daily waiting for an answer. Finally, someone this morning is going to try to have to have it approved within the hour.  It's nice to have a little break because I feel almost completly normal other than lingering fatigue. However, my spine mets cause me intermittent pain and it is just a reminder that the cancer could be having a huge party while I do nothing. I'm praying I get started tomorrow! I hope everyone's rising TM's are an indicator of tumor flare and nothing else.
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2013 08:52AM Bondgirl wrote: formygirls, I'll be praying for you. I think a lot of us have put a lot of eggs in our baskets for this treatment.  I have an MRI on Monday just out of an abundance of caution (I don't have any symptoms that would indicated brain mets other than just high risk factor). I'm still nervous as all get out.  I have had respiratory problems off and on since this Stage IV journey began last summer. I had a pulmonary embolism probaby as a result of the tumor in my left lobe pluera lining.  Sometimes symptoms are worse than others.  It's been mentioned and I think my oncologist is more concerned with another embolism than anything else. My INR levels are monitored regularly.  So it may be combination of lingering damage to my lung and the tumor. It's just strange how it comes and goes and how it was more noticeable after TDM1 infusion.  I'm just hoping for the best. I had nausea but no yacking so I only took Ativan as needed.  They said they would call me in zofran if I needed it but so far so good. I know i just need to relax. I get so hyper vigilant and anxious whenever I am aware of my cancer symptoms or what appear to be cancer symptoms.  I just keep reminding myself this is so not in my control and I just need to be patient and live in the moment.
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: May 17, 2013 02:35PM Bondgirl wrote: Bumping. I know steady rises in tm's not good but how about steady declines? Boards are slow on weekends (good girls). Would like to have some positive vibes going into weekend. Love you all and God Bless! Tera
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2013 04:42PM Bondgirl wrote: Drug was approved at the final hour yesterday! Sitting in infusion chair waiting for UPS man to drop it off. Actually hope they are prepping it in the back now. I'm the first patient in a large practice to be starting. Patient No. 1. Hope I can be a success story for all those to follow! The staff seems excited which is nice.
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: May 16, 2013 07:51AM Bondgirl wrote: Thought we could use some positivity on the board. Went today for lab follow ups and a week and half from 2 treatments. My tm's are about 200 points down. I feel decent especially since doing WBR too but it's always nice to hear some positive news. Keep the faith up ladies. I'm going to enjoy this for next week!
Posts.Title: Anyone on T-DM1? violinfingers Pbjarrett

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 09:23AM Bondgirl wrote: Tiger Blood, a couple months before my stage IV recurrence I completed the Insanity workout and was doing P90x. Best shape of my life then bam stage IV. I think exercise is something very important that we can do and can give us some semblance of control but it's so hard during treatment. I'm easing myself back into it with walking and elliptical. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Do you guys exercise? Tiger_Blood lilylady

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 05:51AM Bondgirl wrote: I do not have bilateral cancer but I do have lung mets (and liver met and possible spinal mets). I am in my 30's with a small child.  I suspect you may have been labeled "rare" because of the bilateral diagnosis. However, it would seem to me at Stage IV that is not as important as your lung met diagnosis. I would suspect since your pathology on both breasts is different you will first get chemo with herceptin.  That is a good thing believe it or not. Have they talked about doing a biopsy on the lung mets to determine pathology that would seem very important? I agree Ebru about spending some time on the Stage IV board and reading the posts. You can usually tell by the heading whether it will be an uplifting post or something depressing and stressful.  Some days I need a dose of reality and I read the scary stuff and then some days I just want positivity so I stay away even though I am always praying for all of us.  You are at the beginning stages of diagnosis which is so scary. Trust that there is hope and that they will find the right treatment for you. Also, because of your "rare" diagnosis have you looked into a second opinion at one of the big research hospitals? MDA, Sloan, Mayo, etc?

Posts.Title: SSDI with stage 4 cancer tclawmen Hrlady53

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 03:16AM Bondgirl wrote: I've been on Kadcyla for several months. Although I developed brain mets in late spring my scans for bone, liver and lung showed regression or stability since starting Kadcyla. I have scans again in 2 weeks and I'm hopeful as my tumor markers continue to slowly decline. I have no side effects from the Kadcyla other than the Herceptin like runny nose and overall fatigue but that is more likely related to whole brain radiation. It's really an easy chemo for most of us. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Kadcyla Experience Please goldengirl12 goldengirl12

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2013 06:41PM Bondgirl wrote: I'm in the same boat as your friend...praying for a tumor flare. My markers were continuing to go up after a few treatments despite complete resolution of liver met.  However, may have had progression in lungs and spine. They are still going up but I have scans in a couple weeks so we aren't changing anything until then.  I would say after only two treatments this could definitely be flare in your friend's case. Is she scheduled for scans? That is the only definitive.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Tumor marker flare cardsfan aelh9355

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2013 08:58AM Bondgirl wrote: I take Ativan to sleep most nights. I spoke to my oncologist about switching to melatonin and she was okay with that (she is hesitant to recommend any herbal or supplements while on chemo). Although, she said if I need the drugs to take them.  I think her thought process is the same as mine as far as drug dependence vs. Stage IV diagnosis and QOL.  I tried the melatonin and it actually makes me really groggy in the morning even with a full night of sleep. Similar to Nyquil for me. For now I'm sticking with the Ativan. I'm hoping that if I get to stable, regression or NED I can cut back on the Ativan and Xanax.  Since I initially had a liver met I worry about all the drugs being processed through my liver. All that being said I believe sleep is so important for our health.
Posts.Title: Sleep Meds kayrnic Brendatrue

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2013 08:43AM Bondgirl wrote: I have that same question to cardsfan seeing as how I'm several treatments in and mine are still rising. So frustrating. Btw, if we are talking baseball I come from a long line of cards fans. :)
Posts.Title: Tumor marker flare cardsfan aelh9355

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2013 08:46AM Bondgirl wrote: I too had mixed emotions when I got my life insurance payout. It's a double edged sword emotionally. However, the financial relief it has brought my family can only be a good thing. We paid off all our debt, refinanced the house so that the payment is manageable on one salary. We are starting a college fund for my daughter. We also have the money to make the regular trips to MDA. Not to mention we plan to travel whenever we can. Don't get inside your head too much on the time frame. I choose to look at is as a blessing in this horrible nightmare.
Posts.Title: ER- PR- HER2+ with liver mets outlived 12 months? KeepingFaith69 KeepingFaith69

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2013 07:59AM Bondgirl wrote: i agree with the others...wait for the trend. My numbers never went down on P/H/T and continued to climb every three weeks. If there is a trend what helped me was knowing that and therefore I was prepared to move on to my next treatment when my scans came back crappy.  However, I pray it's just a blip and the P/H/T continues to work for you.
Posts.Title: Freaked Out......Tumor marker increase. Tiger_Blood cheryl1946

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2013 12:17AM Bondgirl wrote: Thanks ladies. Your posts really uplifted me although I'm back in a funk tonight. My 3rd round being pushed out about a week due to switch in insurance company. They are expediting review but the perjeta causes the delay according to onc office. I was all ready for chemo tomorrow. :( I just don't want to let these rat bastard cancer cells think it's party time. I'm also extemely saddened by the news of Kita. May she rest in peace and may God lift up her young daughter and family. So sad for them and for us all. Tera
Posts.Title: HER2+++ Ladies Bondgirl CAPTJudy

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2012 08:12PM Bondgirl wrote: Tiger, I'm also 35 and on the same combo as you. This is my second time losing my hair and by far worse than the first go around. My daughter was only 2 the first time and it didn't phase her. Now she is 4 and realizes something is wrong. However, she is handling much better than I thought. Let's just hope this combo is kicking our mets along with our hair to the curb!
Posts.Title: Losing Hair for the 3rd time! Tiger_Blood Stefanie

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2013 10:22PM Bondgirl wrote: Jenninmichigan, I've stalked your posts over the last several months and you give us HER gals a lot of hope. It does seem like the majority of HER metsters are us younger ladies. Most days I cope pretty well but the dark thoughts are not very far away. Right now, I'm using the anxiety meds but I'm hoping to get some positive tumor markers next week and see if I can't rely on hope a little bit more than happy pills. I am also doing perjeta/herceptin/taxotere. Third treatment next week. Overall, managing chemo pretty well. The fatigue for me the first couple days is killer and the taste buds are a disaster for about 10 days but I'm taking disability and focusing on myself and my daughter. I couldn't imagine having any other responsibilities on my plate right now. Thanks for all the support. It truly helps to know we are not alone.
Posts.Title: HER2+++ Ladies Bondgirl CAPTJudy

Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: I've had mets to bone, liver and pleural lining for a little over year. Kadcyla has kept me regressing and stable. In the spring diagnosed with brain mets. Too many for knife so did WBR. First scan decent. 2nd MRI progression. My MDA doc says phase 1 trial (which basically has no results yet) or hospice. Wtf? I know all about blood brain barrier but no other options???? I'm her 2 positive and estrogen positive at 46%. He said Tykerb not shown to be effective.Any advice. Hometown Atlanta. Cancer centers of America, Mayo, Sloan, UCLA? Posts.Title: Help! How can this be my only option Bondgirl DancingVeggie

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 04:10PM Bondgirl wrote: thanks ladies. In a better place now. My local oncologist got me an immediate appointment with Kimberly Blackwell (head of breast oncology at Duke and primary researcher for tdm1). I liked her a lot. I have to come off tdm1 because even though keeping systemic mets stable does not cross blood brain barrier. I haven't been on a ton of chemos so we are going to try Tykerb, Xeloda and Herceptin. I know lots of women don't get a response but I'm hoping and praying for best. Dr. Blackwell said nowhere near ready for hospice. Besides stability issues at times and fatigue and minor headaches I feel healthy! Really disappointed with MDA docs attitude although the center itself is still top notch in my opinion.

We have a lot to fight for. My husband is very supportive but I do worry about how my daughter will be raised if my time is cut short. All the best.
Posts.Title: Liver mets & very young children tortoise M-Aug

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2013 03:35AM Bondgirl wrote: I don't even deal with my PCP anymore. Your oncologist should have no problem filling out your paperwork. I'm collecting short term disability now, have been approved for long term and also got accelerated life insurance benefits. I was just diagnosed stage IV in November and I am young and healthy other than this crappy incurable cancer thing. If you get any further hassle I would consider finding a new medical team. Good luck!
Posts.Title: From Stage 0 to Stage IV in 4 months? JillianBarclay Chickadee

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2013 04:10AM Bondgirl wrote: Penny, so sorry! I'm in the waiting room now....literally. Scans yesterday and meet with oncologist to review in bit. I'm pretty sure I've failed on taxotere/herceptin/perjeta. Such a bummer even though I hate taxotere. I think TDM1 next for me. I don't know much about it logistically. Did they give you in details about infusions, side effects, etc.? Guess I will know soon enough. Hope TDM1 is our miracle drug too! All the best. Tera
Posts.Title: Scan today - put me to sleep until I get the results redwolf8812 Bondgirl

Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: Hi ladies. I had recurrence to liver, lungs and bones a year ago. After a couple months on perjeta, taxo and Herceptin I had minor progression and high tumor markers. Switched to Kadcyla which I have had a great response. Unfortunately the cancer took off for refuge in my brain. I did 14 rounds of WBR. It was tough afterwards too. My first 3 month follow up MRI showed regression but still activity. My second follow this week showed growth and worse, new lesions. I got my MDA appt pushed up to little over a week. I don't want to go off Kadcyla but I have feeling they are going to want me to go on tykerb and xeloda. Any experiences with similar situation? Cyber knife not option and want to keep 2nd round of WBR later (especially with side effects). Anyone taking Kadcyla and Tykerb? There is also a clinical trial that the research nurse thinks I should qualify for but I don't know any details. No scary stories please. I'm emotionally fragile. :) "Be Brave" Dx 6/19/2010, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Surgery 11/29/2010 Mastectomy: Right Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/28/2012 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 11/28/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: What is next for brain mets? Bondgirl vickib

Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: Ladies., could use some tips. I know this topic has been talked to death but I could just use some basic info. I was doing awesome on tdm1 but my brain mets didn't react well 6 months after WBR. So going off Tdm1 and starting tykerb, xeloda and Herceptin. I may also get an AI thrown in there. At this point I'm not concerned with my hair I just want as much QOL as possible but am curious about conflicting info about hair loss. Also, anyone combining healthy diet with meds to combat diarrhea that seems to help? I've read some about hand and foot syndrome....any tips? If you ladies can add any tips for a newbie to this combo I appreciate it. :) Tera "Be Brave" Dx 6/19/2010, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Surgery 11/29/2010 Mastectomy: Right Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/28/2012 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 11/28/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Xeloda, tykerb and Herceptin Bondgirl sblankenship

Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: Maybe it's because I didn't pay as much attention until I moved to Stage IV but it just seems like with HER2 progression to stage IV is so common. I know it's because it's so aggressive and I know we are lucky to have so many treatment options but it's just so depressing. It seems like there have been a lot of us lately on the boards moving to stage IV or having progression. I need some positive thoughts and support. Do you all think we truly have the best prognosis as many of our docs are trying to tell us? I need 14 more years (my daughter is four). 3-5 years just isn't going to cut it! "Be Brave" Dx 6/19/2010, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Surgery 11/29/2010 Mastectomy: Right Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/28/2012 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 11/28/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: HER2+++ Ladies Bondgirl CAPTJudy

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2012 01:42PM Bondgirl wrote: I was also recently diagnosed with recurrence with spread to liver and lungs. I also have a 4 year old.  I'm still go from shock to acceptance in the blink of an eye.  Once you have a new treatment plan you will start to feel better and more in control.  I just had my first round of chemo and I am spending as much quality time with my daughter as I can when I feel up to it.  I'm also leaning on my husband to get her out of the house on weekends and my girlfriend who also has young children to offer up playdates. We also sit in the recliner and watch Disney Jr. and color. It makes me feel bad to plop her in front of the tv but I also know that she is thrilled to be in my presence regardless of what we are doing. lol. I take the Ativan, Xanax and the anti-depressants. It's the only way I am able to cope with the emotional overload and fear right now. I'm hoping with time it will get better. Don't be afraid to ask for help. We are superwomen but we need a little help. Lots of hugs.
Posts.Title: looking for hope and hugs leftfootforward aic

Posts.Content: Bondgirl wrote: I was diagnosed with brain mets and had WBR about 2 months ago. They immediately put me on decadron for side effects. I'm sure most of you can identify the extreme downside for being on these for weeks. I began to taper which was slow and my last doses we 2mg every other day. Suddenly last week I ended up with , migraines, dizziness, and jello legs with super low energy. I was out of state with my parents and per my onco she sent me to ER. They did a CT without contrast and it was clear. My doc upped my decadron again and I seem to be doing much better. I have my scheduled post WBR MRI on 24th. Anyway, anyone else have any extreme decadron withdrawal symptoms? How do we ever get past them? "Be Brave" Dx 6/19/2010, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Surgery 11/29/2010 Mastectomy: Right Dx 11/15/2012, IDC, 5cm, Stage IV, Grade 3, 2/9 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Targeted Therapy 11/28/2012 Perjeta (pertuzumab) Chemotherapy 11/28/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Decadron withdrawal? Bondgirl GatorGal

Posts.Content: Mar 7, 2013 06:40AM Bondgirl wrote: Nothing is hopeless. I pray the WBR will take care of those brain mets and the Femara will help the liver and bones but especially the liver. Are you normally 90 lbs or is that because of cancer/treatment?  Have you spoken to your oncologist and nutritionist about trying to get more calories?  Is the swallowing an allergic reaction to the treatment? You are in a terrible position but many women on these boards have come back from worse?  If denial is helping you cope but not keeping you at a standstill then I don't see a problem with it! Lots of hugs and prayers.
Posts.Title: is this hopeless? manysunshine Chickadee
